speech.title: Foreword
content: First email by ***Ray Tomlinson*** in 1971
How many time office workers spend on email correspondence
Common mistakes and their cost
Tips for writing efficient emails

speech.title: Subject
content: Use clear, searchable subject lines 💡
How it can help?

speech.title: Highlight the main idea at the very beginning
content: Journalists technique called the five Ws
Military technique called Bottom Line Up Front
Highlight key facts up top
Add any necessary background or context
Label each section

speech.title: Provide specific dates and times
content: Avoid using inaccurate dates ⏰ like **tomorrow**, **next week** or **yesterday**

speech.title: Highlight and specify your requests
content: **@** tag anyone in a group thread 🚦 who needs to take action
Put the request in a separate paragraph

speech.title: The best emails are simple
content: Many people write more formally than they speak 🤓
In most cases, this is unnecessarily

speech.title: Stay active, not passive
content: Active voice writing is clear and straightforward
It’s more compelling to read

speech.title: Format for clarity
content: Avoid ⚓ huge text blocks
Use headlines, bullets, and numbers
Highlight any sections that demand special attention, or use colors to indicate new headings or topics

speech.title: Include images whenever possible
content: Screenshots, photos, and drawings can replace hundreds of words 🖼️
Tables and spreadsheets can be helpful
It’s relevant and allows you to cut down on the text

speech.title: Squeeze out excess words
content: Emails should be edited
Practice making your emails as short as possible

speech.title: Remember that email isn’t chat
content: Try not to slip into text and chat habits when you’re writing emails

speech.title: Don’t send when you’re stressed
content: Or angry. Or confused and emotional 👿
You might see the situation differently a few hours
Leave the recipient’s name off the email when you’re drafting a difficult message
Share it with a trusted friend or colleague who can offer some outside perspective
